Definitions.Definition_Content: A field homomorphism \\(\sigma: L \longrightarrow L'\\) between two field extensions \\(L / K\\) and \\(L' / K\\) is called a \\(K\\)-homomorphism if it restricts to the identity map on \\(K\\).

Definitions.Concept_Name: Splitting field of Family of Polynomials
Definitions.Definition_Content: A splitting field of a family of nonconstant polynomials \\(\mathfrak{F}=(f_i)_{i \in I}, f_i \in K[X]\\) over a field \\(K\\) is a field \\(L\\) extending \\(K\\) such that: (i) Every polynomial \\(f_i\\) decomposes into a product of linear factors over \\(L\\). (ii) The extension \\(L / K\\) is generated by the zeros of the polynomials \\(f_i\\).

A normal field extension is an extension field that is the splitting field of a family of polynomials from the base field. It is a prestage to Galois extensions. An algebraic field extension \\(K \subset L\\) is called normal if it satisfies the equivalent conditions of Theorem 4: (i) Every \\(K\\)-homomorphism \\(L \longrightarrow \bar{L}\\) into an algebraic closure \\(\bar{L}\\) of \\(L\\) restricts to an automorphism of \\(L\\). (ii) \\(L\\) is a splitting field of a family of polynomials in \\(K[X]\\). (iii) Every irreducible polynomial in \\(K[X]\\) that admits a zero in \\(L\\) decomposes over \\(L\\) completely into linear factors.

Theorems.Theorem_Content: Let \\(L_1, L_2\\) be two splitting fields of a family \\(\mathfrak{F}\\) of nonconstant polynomials in \\(K[X]\\), for a field \\(K\\), and let \\(\bar{L}_2\\) be an algebraic closure of \\(L_2\\). Then every \\(K\\)-homomorphism \\(\bar{\sigma}: L_1 \longrightarrow \bar{L}_2\\) restricts to a \\(K\\)-isomorphism \\(\sigma: L_1 \xrightarrow{\sim} L_2\\).
Let \\(L_1, L_2\\) be two splitting fields of a family of nonconstant polynomials in \\(K[X]\\). Then there exists a \\(K\\)-isomorphism \\(L_1 \xrightarrow{\sim} L_2\\).

The following conditions are equivalent for a field \\(K\\) and an algebraic extension \\(K \subset L\\): (i) Every \\(K\\)-homomorphism \\(L \longrightarrow \bar{L}\\) into an algebraic closure \\(\bar{L}\\) of \\(L\\) restricts to an automorphism of \\(L\\). (ii) \\(L\\) is a splitting field of a family of polynomials in \\(K[X]\\). (iii) Every irreducible polynomial in \\(K[X]\\) that admits a zero in \\(L\\) decomposes over \\(L\\) completely into linear factors.

Let \\(L / K\\) be an algebraic field extension. (i) \\(L / K\\) admits a normal closure \\(L' / K\\), where \\(L'\\) is unique up to (noncanonical) isomorphism over \\(L\\). (ii) \\(L' / K\\) is finite if \\(L / K\\) is finite. (iii) If \\(M / L\\) is an algebraic field extension such that \\(M / K\\) is normal, we can choose \\(L'\\) as an intermediate field of \\(M / L\\). In this case, \\(L'\\) is unique. More precisely, if \\(\left(\sigma_i\right)_{i \in I}\\) is the family of all \\(K\\)-homomorphisms from \\(L\\) to \\(M\\), then \\(L'\\) is \\(K\left(\sigma_i(L) ; i \in I\right)\\). We call \\(L'\\) the normal closure of \\(L\\) in \\(M\\).
